Article Enhancing oxygen reduction of Fe-N-C active sites onto graphene via bismuth sacrifice for Zn-air batteries Zhiyuan Yang a Yan Zhang a Juanding Xiao a Junying Wang b * Junzhong Wang a * a Institutes of Physical Science and Information Technology, Anhui Graphene Carbon Fiber Materials Research Center, Anhui University, Hefei 230601, Anhui, China Institutes of Physical Science and Information Technology Anhui Graphene Carbon Fiber Materials Research Center Anhui University Hefei Anhui 230601 China Institutes of Physical Science and Information Technology, Anhui Graphene Carbon Fiber Materials Research Center, Anhui University, Hefei 230601, Anhui, China b Shanxi Key Laboratory of Carbon Materials, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, China Shanxi Key Laboratory of Carbon Materials Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 China Shanxi Key Laboratory of Carbon Materials, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, China * Corresponding author. ABSTRACT Synthesizing low-cost electrocatalysts with rich metal-nitrogen-carbon active sites for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is critical for developing high-performance Zn-air batteries. However, it is challenging for the pyrolysis cheap molecular precursors (such as melamine and iron salts) is challenging because of the spontaneous aggregation of metal components and undesired byproducts during pyrolysis. Herein, we describe an approach to generate graphene-supported accessible Fe-N-C active sites by introducing a removable bismuth compound that efficiently inhibits the formation of iron-related particles and tubular carbon structures. The graphene-supported Fe(Bi)-N-C electrocatalyst exhibited high ORR activity under both alkaline (E 1/2 ~0.916 V) and acidic (E 1/2 ~0.784 V) conditions, along with excellent durability (15 mV degradation after 10 k cycles accelerated test). Using the catalytic material as the cathode, the Zn-air battery delivered a high power density of 201.4 mW cm–2 and a high stability over 1000 cycles. This investigation presents a promising controlled pyrolysis solution for the scalable synthesis of low-cost, high-performance metal-nitrogen-carbon-based catalytic materials. Graphical Abstract A graphene supported Fe(Bi)-N-C electrocatalyst, synthesized through bismuth-mediated pyrolysis, exhibits high activity (E 1/2 0.916 V) and durability for oxygen reduction reaction, and also enables high performance Zn-air battery (201.4 mW cm–2, 1000 cycles). Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Bismuth Graphene Zn-air battery Fe-N-C 1 Introduction The green synthesis of low-cost catalytic materials for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is critical for proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and metal-air batteries [1–4]. FeN4 single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been considered potential alternatives to expensive Pt-based catalysts for the ORR owing to their promising ORR performance, abundance, and structural tunability at the atomic level [5–9]. Several studies have reported the annealing and carbonization of cheap molecular precursors (such as melamine and iron salts) to obtain metal-carbon-nitrogen catalytic sites [10–13]. Nevertheless, inexpensive precursors with weak covalent linkages tend to agglomerate to form metal-based hard particles during pyrolysis, limiting the maximum utilization rate of a single Fe atom [10–16]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOF), proven to be good precursors for pyrolyzed microporous carbon loaded with ORR atomic sites, improve the density of catalytic sites through various synthesis approaches. For example, Zn works as a sacrificial metal for annealing zeolitic imidazolate framework to form a carbon-nitrogen matrix to improve Fe-N-C sites; metal Zn, with its relatively low boiling point (907 °C), can be removed and replaced by iron at over 900 °C [17,18]. Substituting Zn with Cd as a sacrificial metal facilitates the formation of high-density Fe single atoms, resulting in improved ORR performance [19]. Unfortunately, the high price of methylimidazole linkers hinders their practical industrial application, thus making it necessary to explore a new approach to extend the possibility of designing sacrificial bonds in Fe-N-C catalysts to enhance the ORR activity, as the selective cleavage of sacrificial bonds enables fine-tuning of the local coordination environment and energy level of the Fe center [20,21]. Herein, we describe an approach for preparing accessible FeN4 active sites anchored on graphene, exhibiting a high-performance oxygen reduction reaction through bi-composition intermediate pyrolysis. We design a cheap precursor system consisting of melamine, graphene, FeCl3, and Bi(NO3)3·5H2O. The synthesis strategy involves using a bismuth compound as a sacrificial composition, graphene as a conductive support, and applying FeCl3 as a precursor for the active site. FeCl3 also facilitated the intercalation of few-layer graphene and prevented graphene stacking. The added bismuth compound played a role in inhibiting the formation of crystalline iron particles upon annealing and enhancing the density of the Fe-N-C sites. Considering the boiling point of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O is 80 °C, much lower than that of FeCl3 at 320 °C, Bi(NO3)3·5H2O is more volatile than FeCl3 during intercalation [22]. Under the synthetic conditions described in this paper, bismuth or bismuth oxide produced by the high-temperature pyrolysis of the precursor has no carbon layer on its surface, making it easier to remove them using hot acids. Fe compounds form Fe3C and Fe after high-temperature treatment. Considering Fe3C is covered by carbon tubes and cannot be completely removed using hot acids, we believe that bismuth compounds are easier to remove than iron precursors during the synthesis and purification process, providing positions occupied by atomic Fe, thus increasing the density of isolated Fe-N-C active sites. Owing to these attributes of bismuth and iron, the synthesized Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A electrocatalyst resulting from cheap precursors exhibits outstanding ORR activity, featuring a high half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.916 V in 0.1 mol L–1 KOH and an E 1/2 of 0.784 V in a 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 electrolyte and a remarkable durability of 10000 cycles. Furthermore, this electrocatalyst offers high performance in Zn-air batteries, achieving a high peak power density of 201.4 mW cm–2 with a high specific capacity. Hence, the proposed approach is a relatively low-cost and simple process for obtaining high-performance graphene/carbon-supported iron-nitrogen-carbon catalytic materials. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials preparation Typically, 0.05 g of graphene, 0.81 g of anhydrous FeCl3, 0.25 g of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, and 5.0 g of melamine were mixed and ball-milled in a planetary ball miller at 900 r min–1 for 6 h. The mixed powder was annealed at 900 °C for 2 h under Ar gas flow at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 (the product is marked as Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-H). The samples Fe-N-C/G-H, (Bi)-N-C/G-H, and N-C/G-H were synthesized using the same procedure as that used for Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-H, with a controlling precursor. All resulting powders were ground and immersed in 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4 solution at 80 °C for 24 h under stirring, then dried and heated at 800 °C under argon atmosphere for 2 h at a ramping rate of 5 °C min–1. The final products are denoted as Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, Fe-N-C/G-A, (Bi)-N-C/G-A, and N-C/G-A, respectively. 2.2 Materials characterizations The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker AXS GmbH in the 2θ range of 10° to 80°, with the morphologies characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Regulus 8230) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-F200). Sub-angstrom-resolution high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and X-ray energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were performed using a JEOL Titan Themis Z microscope at 300 kV. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms were obtained using an ASAP 2460 physisorption analyzer (Micrometrics, US), with the specific surface area and pore profiles calculated based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda model, respectively. A Renishaw Via-Reflex spectrometer (λ ex = 532 nm) was employed to obtain Raman spectra. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Thermofisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer using a monochromatic Al-Kα source. X-ray absorption fine structure spectra (Fe K-edge) were collected at the BL14W1 station at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). The storage ring of the SSRF was operated at 3.0 GeV with a maximum current of 200 mA. Using a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator, data were collected in transmission mode using an ionization chamber for Fe foil, FeO, and Fe2O3, respectively. All spectra were collected under ambient conditions. The raw XAS data were processed using Athena software, with curve fitting performed using the Artemis software of the IFEFFIT software packages. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements All the measurements were performed using a three-electrode system on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation at room temperature. A glassy carbon (GC) round disk electrode (RDE) or rotating-ring disk electrode (RRDE) immersed in the as-prepared samples was used as the working electrode, with an Ag/AgCl electrode (filled with saturated KCl solution) and graphite rods used as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. All potentials in the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were corrected using iR compensation and converted to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The catalyst (5 mg) was dispersed in 0.97 mL of water-ethanol solution (V:V = 2:1), with 30 μL of Nafion solution (Sigma Aldrich, 5 wt%) added subsequently. The mixture was stirred ultrasonically for 1 h to obtain a homogeneous ink. Next, 20 μL of the ink was pipetted onto a glassy carbon rotating disk electrode with a diameter of 5 mm and dried for 30 min at room temperature, leading to a catalyst loading of 0.52 mg cm–2. Before the ORR tests, the electrolytes were bubbled with N2 or O2 for 30 min to make the system saturate them. For the ORR at the RDE, LSV was performed at a scanning rate of 5 mV s–1 at various rotation speeds (400, 625, 900, 1225, 1600, and 2025 rpm) in O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 KOH and 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 solutions. The kinetic current of the electrocatalyst and electron transfer number were determined using the Koutechy-Levich (K-L) equation: (1) 1/J = 1/J L + 1/J K = 1/Bω 0.5 + 1/J K (1) (2) B = 0.62nFC 0(D 0)2/3 ν –1/6 (3) J K = nFkC 0 where J is the measured current density; J K and J L are the kinetic and diffusion-limiting current densities, respectively. B was determined from the slope of the K-L equation: F is the Faraday constant (F = 96485 C mol–1), ω is the angular velocity of the disk, the constant of 0.62 is adopted when the rotation speed is expressed in rad s–1, n is the electron transfer number, C 0 is the saturated concentration of O2 (1.2×10–6 mol cm–3) in alkaline or acidic aqueous solutions, D 0 is the diffusion coefficient of O2 (1.9 × 10–5 cm2 s–1) and ν is the kinetic viscosity (0.01 cm2 s–1). For the RRDE measurements, the disk electrode was scanned cathodically at a rate of 5 mV s–1, with the ring potential kept constant at 1.2 V vs. RHE. The peroxide percentage (HO2 –) and the electron transfer number (n) were determined by the following equations: (4) H O 2 = 200 × I R / N I D + I R / N (5) n = 4 × I D I D + I R / N where I D is the disk current, I R is the ring current, and N is the current-collection efficiency of the Pt ring. N was determined to be 0.37. The mass activity (MA) and turnover frequency (TOF) of the catalysts are defined as follows: (6) mass activity = j k × A m metal where j k is the kinetic current density at 0.85 V, A is the geometric electrode area, and m metal is the mass loading of the electrode. (7) TOF = j k × A × N e n × m metal × N A / M where Ne is the electron number per Coulomb (6.24 × 1018), N A is the Avogadro constant, and M is the molar mass of Fe. 2.4 Zn-air battery test The performances of the Zn-air batteries were evaluated using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E) and a battery test system in a homemade cell. The air cathode was fabricated by dipping the catalyst ink onto carbon paper under 0.5 mg cm–2 loading and overnight drying. A well-polished Zn plate with a thickness of 0.2 mm was used as the anode, while a mixed solution of 6 mol L–1 KOH and 0.2 mol L–1 Zn(OAc)2 was used as the electrolyte. 3 Results and Discussion Herein, we report the preparation of an Fe-N x -C electrocatalyst using Bi as the sacrificial metal (SM) instead of Zn (details can be found in the experimental section). Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was selected because of its relatively low boiling point. Its boiling point is 80 °C lower than that of ZnCl2 (732 °C), which may facilitate the preparation of single atom Fe-N x active sites at a reduced temperature. In the first step, Anhydrous FeCl3 (boiling point, ~316 °C) and Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was mixed with few-layer graphene and pyrolysis at high temperature in Ar. After washing with acid and annealing under an argon atmosphere, isolated single-atom iron on nitrogen-doped graphene frameworks (Fe-N x -C) were obtained (Fig. 1 ). As shown in Fig. 2(a) , the XRD pattern of N-C/G shows two broad peaks at 26.6° and 54.7°, which are indexed to the (002) and (101) planes of N-doped graphitic carbon, respectively [23,24]. The (Bi)-N-C/G-H and Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-H samples showed typical peaks at 27.1°, 37.9°, 39.6°, 45.8°, 48.6°, 55.6°, 62.1°, and 64.4°, assigned to metallic Bi (PDF 44-1246), implying the carbothermic reduction of Bi(NO3)3 to form metallic Bi (Bi0) [25]. The other three peaks located at 27.3°, 33.5°, and 47.1° correspond to Bi2O3 (PDF 27-0050), derived from the decomposition of Bi(NO3)3 at high temperatures. The peaks of Fe-N-C/G-H and Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-H samples situated at 26.4°, 37.7°, 37.6°, 39.7°, 42.8°, 43.7°, 44.5°, 44.9°, 45.8°, 48.3°, 48.5°, 49.1°, 51.8°, 54.1°, and 54.3°, corresponded to that of Fe3C (PDF 35-0772), possibly owing to the carbothermic reduction of the FeCl3 enabled the self-incorporation of Fe3+ into the carbon skeleton to form Fe3C nanoparticles (Fig. S1) [26]. Peaks of iron species were observed at 44.6°, 65.0°, probably owing to the carbothermal reduction of iron ions to elemental iron (Fe0) [27]. After acidic etching, the characteristic peaks at 37.6°, 43.7°, 44.9°, 51.8°, and 54.3° of the Fe-N-C/G-A sample belonging to the Fe3C (PDF 35-0772) species were observed (Figs. 2(b) and S2). No iron species peaks were observed in Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, probably because of the low iron content, as verified by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (Table S1). After Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A and Fe-N-C/G-A were washed with hot acid, the Fe content was 1.9 wt% and 10.8 wt%, respectively, proving that Fe compounds were easy to gather in the absence of bismuth nitrate. Furthermore, it reacts with melamine to form coated nanotubes that are not easily removed by hot acids. After the sample was washed with hot acid, the Bi content were 0.05 wt% and 0.01 wt% of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A and (Bi)-N-C/G-A, respectively. While the Bi compound reacts with the nitrogen source to form Bi-N-C, the instability leads to the formation of more Fe-N-C sites. The fact that Bi was not completely removed from the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A samples is evidence that very little Bi-N-C was formed. The elemental Bi in (Bi)-N-C/G-A was completely removed using hot acid. As shown in Fig. S2, the formed iron carbide particles were armored using a bamboo-like carbon tube, preventing leaching during the acidic workup, and remaining in the Fe-N-C/G-A sample [28]. No clear nanoparticles were found during the TEM observations, and only irregular carbon nanosheet structures were observed for the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A sample, indicating the complete removal of these species by hot acidic washing (Figs. 3(a), (b), and S3). Fe plays a key role in the formation of bamboo-like carbon tubes and flocculent carbon nanostructures [29]. Multiple carbon nanostructures with different iron content in raw materials can be synthesized from the migration and rearrangement of carbon atoms catalyzed by active iron atoms at high temperature treatment process (900 °C) [30]. When the amount of iron precursor was decreased, the as-prepared Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A sample comprised flocculent, thin, and wrinkled carbon nanostructures instead of bamboo-like carbon tubes, as shown in Figs. 3(a), (b), and S3. When the bismuth precursor was absent during the preparation of Fe-N-C/G-A, larger nanoparticles approximately 20 nm in size appeared (Fig. S2). Raman spectra were recorded to determine the degree of disorder in the acid-etched samples. Two distinct peaks related to the D band (approximately 1340 cm–1) and G band (approximately 1590 cm–1), which provide information on the disorder and crystallinity of the sp 2 carbon materials, were observed (Fig. 2(c)) [31]. The normalized area ratio of the D-band and G-bands (I D/I G) provides information on the degree of disorder in carbon materials induced by heteroatom doping. The I D/I G value increased gradually from 0.472 to 0.962 for the N-C/G-A, (Bi)-N-C/G-A, Fe-N-C/G-A, and Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A samples with increasing N, Fe, and O heteroatom contents, revealing an increase in the number of defects and disordered carbons in the structure [32]. Fig. 2(d) shows the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the samples washed with hot acid. The pore size distributions of the three samples (inset of Fig. 2(d), Table S2) are different, indicating that the presence of Bi(NO3)3 significantly affected the mesopore distribution in the catalyst. Concretely, the specific surface areas of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, Fe-N-C/G-A, and (Bi)-N-C/G-A based on BET are 281.4, 241.2, and 101.1 m2 g–1, respectively. Detailed pore size distributions were obtained using a nonlocal density functional theory model, where the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A sample has a 1.7 nm micropore, which shows that Fe-N-C/G-A and (Bi)-N-C/G-A had a large number of mesopores with a pore width of 2.4 nm (Fig. 2(d)). Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis of the material further shows that bismuth can effectively change the physical structure of the material, which may be due to the low melting point of Bi(NO3)3, forming a large number of small droplets during the heating process, which acts as a sacrificial agent and thus affects the structure of the carbon. Introducing Bi(NO3)3 effectively inhibits the formation of Fe3C, causes the sample to form a flake structure (Figs. 3(a) and (b) ), and promotes mass transfer. The HAADF-STEM image and corresponding elemental mapping analysis of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A revealed that Fe, N, and C were distributed homogenously throughout the architecture (Figs. 3(c) and (d)). STEM further verified that Fe was mainly distributed in the form of dispersed isolated atoms, and the absence of crystalline Fe phases or clusters in the catalyst was confirmed by the XRD results (Figs. 3(e), S4, and 2(b)) [33]. Electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) coupled with microscopy indicated the presence of C, N, and Fe atoms. The weak signal of the Fe L2,3 edge is due to the relatively low scattering cross-section and the small amount of Fe in the catalyst (inset of Fig. 3(f)). To obtain insights into the elemental composition and surface chemical binding states of the Fe-N-C/G-A and Fe(Bi)–N-C/G-A samples, various X-ray spectroscopy-based techniques were employed. The survey spectrum of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A displays distinctive peaks of Fe, N, O, and C, revealing the successful doping of Fe and N atoms in the carbon matrix (Fig. 4(a) ). The Bi signal was almost invisible because of the low atomic metal content of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A (Fig. 4(a)). The N 1s high-resolution spectra showed four distinct peaks (located at 398.3, 399.3, 401.1, and 402.9 eV) corresponding to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N or Fe-N x , graphitic N, and oxygenated N species, respectively (Fig. 4(c)). The high-resolution Fe 2p spectra could be subdivided into four groups: Fe2+ 2p 3/2 (710.4 eV), Fe3+ 2p 3/2 (713.7 eV), Fe2+ 2p 1/2 (723.3 eV), and Fe3+ 2p 1/2 (728.1 eV). The primary peak located at 707.7 eV corresponding to the Fe 2p 2/3 region, suggesting that Fe3C was embedded in the graphitic carbon layers [34]. The peak at 707.5 eV is attributable to the Fe 2p 3/2 signal of metallic Fe3C species [35]. Meanwhile another peak at 707.8 eV attributed to Fe3C [34,35] (Fig. 4(b)), corresponding to the results of XRD, suggesting the coexistence of Fe-N x and FeC x species in Fe-N-C/G-A and the available of only Fe-N x structures in Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A. Such iron-nitrogen structures are typical catalytically active sites for the ORR/OER reported for various types of Fe-N x -C catalysts [35]. The presence of iron-nitrogen peaks indicated that single-atomic iron moieties were coordinated by nitrogen species. The Bi 4f spectrum shows a spin-orbit split doublet with Bi 4f 5/2 at 164.8 eV, attributed to Bi3+ (Fig. S5) [35–37]. Bi-N-C may have been formed, become unstable, and replaced by Fe to form more Fe-N-C active sites. Residual Bi is not the main active species, and Bi is mainly sacrificial for improving the ORR performance. To further analyze the atomic-scale structure and valence state of Fe, Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A was investigated using synchrotron-based X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy, including Fe K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) with reference to Fe foil, FeO, Fe2O3, and FePc. The XANES spectra show a white-line intensity of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A located between FeO and Fe2O3, indicating that the oxidation state of Fe lies between +2 and +3 (Figs. 5(a) and S6), consistent with the XPS results (Fig. 4(b)). Fig. 5(b) shows the corresponding k3-weighted Fourier transform EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) spectra. Compared with Fe foil and FePc, the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A shows a dominant peak at ~1.4 Å, assigning to Fe-N/Fe-O backscattering [8]. Compared with Fe foil and FePc, the Fe-N-C/G-A shows a primary peak at 2.17 Å together with a shoulder peak at around 1.46 Å, corresponding to the Fe–Fe and Fe–N scattering paths, respectively. These results confirm the coexistence of Fe3C and Fe single atoms in Fe-N-C/G-A. To further determine whether Fe coordinated with N or O, we fitted the least-squares EXAFS curve to the first coordination shell of the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A sample using the FePc structure as a reference (Fig. 5(c)). The fittings match well with the experimental data, with the isolated Fe atoms in Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A can be well-fitted with approximately four N atoms with an average Fe–N bond distance of 1.98 Å (Table S3 and Fig. S7). The EXAFS fitting results of Fe-N-C/G-A suggest that the coordination of the Fe species matches well with that of Fe-Fe, in accordance with the Fe3C via XPS and analysis (Fig. 5(d)). A more powerful Fe K-edge wavelet transform EXAFS (WT-EXAFS) was also employed to investigate the local structure of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A because of its high resolution in both the K and R spaces (Fig. 5(e)). The wavelet transformed EXAFS (WT-EXAFS) contour map showed an intense peak at R ~1.4 Å and K ~4.7 Å–1 for the Fe-N first shell, well-fitted with those observed for FePc and Fe foil, respectively (Fig. 5(e)). No signal corresponding to Fe-Fe bonds was detected (R ~2.2 Å and K ~8.8 Å–1) [39]. These results indicate that the isolated Fe sites were atomically dispersed and stabilized by the N atoms of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, which agrees well with the HAADF-STEM and XPS results. Compared with Fe-N-C/G-A, the residual Fe content increased with the addition of Bi, as analyzed by XPS (Table S4) and explained as follows: during the pyrolysis treatment under an argon atmosphere, on the one hand, melamine underwent a pyrolysis-polymerization process to generate N-doped porous carbon; on the other hand, the metal salt was reduced at high temperatures by the generated carbon [40]. Premixed Bi can vary the distance between adjacent Fe atoms and provide more free N x sites, thereby preventing the formation of Fe-Fe bonds at high temperatures [41]. After the first high-temperature treatment, most Bi atoms were removed by washing with concentrated hot acid. We further put forward three possible observations: (1) The remaining Bi sites generate free N sites during post-pyrolysis, which are beneficial for the stabilization of Fe single atoms to form Fe-N4 species via metalation. (2) Partial residual coordinated Bi within the obtained Bi-N4 with Fe and Bi was exchanged between Bi-N4 and FeCl3 via high-temperature transmetalation during post-annealing. (3) After the addition of bismuth nitrate, the N-metal (Pyrrolic N) peak ratio of XPS significantly increased (Fig. 4(d)), indicating that Bi-N was fractured and part of it formed Fe-N. These observations led us to propose that Fe-N4 sites are formed by high-temperature demetallization. The electrocatalytic ORR properties of the synthesized catalysts were measured using a rotating disk electrode (RDE) in an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte with a three-electrode system. Initially, CV curves were measured in an N2 and O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte. As shown in Fig. S8, Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A showed an apparent oxygen reduction peak at approximately 0.893 V under O2-saturated conditions, demonstrating an evident oxygen reduction process. The ORR activities of the electrocatalysts were further examined by RDE in an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L–1 KOH solution. As shown in Fig. 6(a) , the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst exhibits an onset potential (E onset) of 1.058 V and a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.916 V, outperforming those of Fe-N-C/G-A (E onset = 1.021 V, E 1/2 = 0.866 V), (Bi)-N-C/G-A (E onset = 0.849 V, E 1/2 = 0.730 V), and N-C/G-A (E onset = 0.900 V, E 1/2 = 0.759 V), and clearly more positive than that of commercial 20% Pt/C (E onset = 0.978 V, E 1/2 = 0.873 V)—also better that of most non-precious metal ORR catalysts reported in the literatures (Table S5). The half-wave potential of Fe-N-C/G-A was significantly more negative than that of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, indicating that the Fe3C particles in Fe-N-C/G-A contributed negligible ORR activity. Therefore, Bi, as a sacrificial metal, inhibited the agglomeration of Fe and improved the utilization of single-atom Fe. The performance of (Bi)-N-C/G-A was not ideal, which may be because Bi-N x is unstable or Bi volatilization removes part of the N source, resulting in a low-limit current density. The melting point of Bi is lower than that of Fe, and bismuth carbide particles are not easily formed. The kinetic current density of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A reaches 10.41 mA cm–2 at 0.9 V, six times higher than that of Fe-N-C/G-A (1.66 mA cm–2) and four times higher than that of Pt/C (2.55 mA cm–2), as shown in Fig. 6(b). As shown in Fig. 6(c), the calculated ORR Tafel slope for Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A is 59 mV dec–1, lower than those of Fe-N-C/G-A (80 mV dec–1), (Bi)-N-C/G-A (93 mV dec–1), N-C/G-A (88 mV dec–1), and Pt/C (80 mV dec–1), demonstrating that Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A displays more favorable. To gain further insight into the reaction mechanism of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, RDE tests were performed at different rotation speeds ranging from 400 to 2025 rpm. The K-L plots for Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, obtained from the RDE polarization curves at different rotation speeds (Fig. 6(d)), presented nearly parallel fitting lines, suggesting first-order reaction kinetics with respect to O2 concentration and a potentially independent electron transfer rate. The high electron transfer rate was confirmed by RRDE tests (Figs. 6(d) and 6(e)), demonstrating a near-four-electron ORR pathway over single Fe-N4 sites. The active surface area measured by double-layer capacitance(C dl) is 37.1 mF cm–2 for Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, higher than that of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A (13.8 mF cm–2), indicating the higher electrochemical active surface area of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst [42], attributed to the large specific area and defective network of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst (Figs. 2, 3, 6(g), S3 and S8). As shown in Fig. 6(f), only 15 mV of decay in E 1/2 was recorded after 10 k cycles for Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A in 0.1 mol L–1 KOH, less than that of Pt/C (36 mV) and Fe-N-C/G-A (20 mV), demonstrating that the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst also exhibited excellent durability. The results showed that graphene may inhibit carbon corrosion of the carbon carrier and improve the durability of the cathode ORR. In addition, the kinetic current density was normalized to the loading mass of the catalyst to obtain the kinetic mass activity (MA). As shown in Fig. S9, the MA of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A is determined to be 3228 A g–1. The TOF of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A at a constant potential of 0.85 V was 0.465 s–1. These results suggest a higher utilization of active sites for Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A than for commercial Pt/C. Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst also shows good ORR performance in 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 at 1600 r min–1 (Fig. 6(h)), the half-wave potential (E 1/2) is 0.784 V, slightly lower than that of 20% Pt/C (E 1/2 = 0.807 V), but higher than that of Fe-N-C/G-A (E 1/2 = 0.658 V), (Bi)-N-C/G-A and N-C/G-A, revealing that introduction of the Bi(NO3)3 source into the reaction precursor played a vital role in increasing the Fe-N x sties amount, as evidence by XRD, TEM, ICP-AES, and HAADF-STEM results. The (Bi)-N-C/G-A and N-C/G-A catalysts had almost no limiting current, indicating that the reaction was primarily controlled by kinetics. Our data suggest that the use of Bi as an SM allows for the formation of a high density of single-atom structures and high ORR activity of the Fe(Bi)-C-N/G-A electrocatalyst. Among five catalysts, Fe(Bi)-C-N/G-A shows the highest ORR activity in terms of Tafel slope of 56 mV dec–1 (Fig. S10(a)). In the potential window of 0.1–0.6 V, the H2O2 yields were below 3%, whereas the electron transfer numbers are above 3.9 for the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, Fe-N-C/G-A, and Pt/C catalysts (Figs. S10(c) and (d)), indicating a four-electron ORR. The stabilities of the developed catalysts were also evaluated in a half-cell (Fig. S10(b)). After 10,000 potential cycles between 0.2 and 1.0 V vs. RHE in an O2-purged 0.1 mol L–1 HClO4 at ambient temperature, Fe(Bi)-C-N/G-A demonstrates the best stability with an E 1/2 loss of only 19 mV. These results demonstrate that the isolated Fe-N4 sites accounted for the high activity observed in various types of non-PGM ORR catalysts. Owing to the excellent ORR property of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A, we further examine the electrochemical performance of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A as a cathode for ZABs. Fig. 7(a) shows a schematic illustration of the structure and OCV plots of the liquid ZABs. The homemade Zn-air battery with the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst showed a voltage plateau of 1.51 V, higher than that of the cell with Fe-N-C/G-A (1.45 V) and Pt/C (1.48 V), as well as most electrocatalysts reported in the literature (Fig. 7(a) and Table S5). Importantly, the battery with Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst displayed a peak power density of 201.4 mW cm–2 (Fig. 7(b)), higher than that of commercial Pt/C (151.7 mW cm–2) and other reported Fe-N-based ZABs (Table S6). The outstanding discharge performance of the ZAB with Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A can be attributed to the abundant active sites and fast charge/mass transfer. The ZAB with the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A catalyst delivered a specific capacity of 839 mA h g–1 higher than those of Fe-N-C/G-A (709 mA h g–1) and Pt/C (761 mA h g–1) at a discharge current density of 20 mA cm–2 (Fig. 7(c)). Furthermore, Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A + RuO2 showed no significant voltage drops during 1000 cycles of repeated charge-discharge at 5 mA cm–2, whereas the voltage gap of Pt/C + RuO2 increased significantly, revealing the excellent catalytic activity and stability of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A as an air cathode for ZABs (Fig. 7(d)). The primary ZAB results further confirmed that the Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A electrocatalyst exhibited distinct ORR performance in terms of high onset potential, high half-wave potential, high kinetic current density, high open-circuit potential, and excellent durability. 4 Conclusions In summary, we presented a simple annealing process for a cheap precursor towards a high-performance graphene-supported Fe-N-C catalyst by employing a bismuth compound as a sacrificial agent. Comparative experiments indicated that bismuth species can inhibit the formation of iron-related nanoparticles and tuberous carbon by-products from an inexpensive precursor of melamine and iron salt. The product had an improved specific surface area and 3D sheet morphology, enhancing the utilization of the atomically dispersed FeN4 active sites, thus leading to improved ORR catalytic performance. We believe that Bi-N-C formation during annealing allows the Bi vacancies to be replaced by Fe, facilitating the formation of additional FeN4 active sites. The unique structure resulting from the simple annealing process contributes to the outstanding ORR performance of Fe(Bi)-N-C/G-A in both alkaline (E 1/2 ~0.916 V) and acidic (E 1/2 ~0.784 V) environments and remarkable durability with minimal loss after 10000 cycles as well as a high peak power density of 201.4 mW cm–2 of Zn-air batteries. Our investigation provides a simple and rational strategy for developing low-cost and highly efficient non-precious-metal-based catalysts for energy conversion and storage applications. coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Synthesizing low-cost electrocatalysts with rich metal-nitrogen-carbon active sites for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is critical for developing high-performance Zn-air batteries. However, it is challenging for the pyrolysis cheap molecular precursors (such as melamine and iron salts) is challenging because of the spontaneous aggregation of metal components and undesired byproducts during pyrolysis. Herein, we describe an approach to generate graphene-supported accessible Fe-N-C active sites by introducing a removable bismuth compound that efficiently inhibits the formation of iron-related particles and tubular carbon structures. The graphene-supported Fe(Bi)-N-C electrocatalyst exhibited high ORR activity under both alkaline (E 1/2 ~0.916 V) and acidic (E 1/2 ~0.784 V) conditions, along with excellent durability (15 mV degradation after 10 k cycles accelerated test). Using the catalytic material as the cathode, the Zn-air battery delivered a high power density of 201.4 mW cm–2 and a high stability over 1000 cycles. This investigation presents a promising controlled pyrolysis solution for the scalable synthesis of low-cost, high-performance metal-nitrogen-carbon-based catalytic materials.

coredata.dc:title: Enhancing oxygen reduction of Fe-N-C active sites onto graphene via bismuth sacrifice for Zn-air batteries
